item.title: Street lights not working, 30th September
item.description:
Only CW60 and CW56 are working slong this path. This is the third year running that I'm reporting this. The last couple of years Peabody has said it's been passed on to a contractor but nothing gets fixed. Please can you get this sorted for the Thamesmead residents that use it.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Bayliss Avenue, London

item.title: Large flytip, 30th September
item.description:
Large rubbish pile Again some people from Richborough Close and surrounding Closes seem to belive if they flytip rubbish at this location it will automatically be collected by Bromley council. I can't be bothered to take a picture and get abuse from idiots asking why I'm taking pictures of their flytiped rubbish as they stand at the top of the road smoking and dealing their drugs. I do feel that at some point the rubbish pile will probably be set on fire though.

item.title: Slab loose and cement cracked, pair of steps in Kingswood Rd 2m SW of jct with Mays Hill Rd, Shortlands - upper slab nearest the crossroads., 30th September
item.description:
Slab loose and cement cracked, pair of steps in Kingswood Rd 2m SW of jct with Mays Hill Rd, Shortlands - upper slab nearest the crossroads. Displaced slab first seen 10/9/25 (2nd and 3rd photos) Steps seen again 29/9/25. (First photo) The displaced slab is now back on alignment but it has not been cemented in place, now has the cracked infill kerb cement been replaced. The slab is therefore just loose and weight on the overhanging edge can pivot the slab. Please cement the slab in place and replace the broken infill kerb cement. Please note that these two steps also present a hazard as they are of longstanfing mismatching riser heights. Complaint outstanding, awaiting reply from a ward councillor.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Kingswood Road, Shortlands, London
Report on FixMyStreet

Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: "Flags remaining in place in Bexley" - Request for Clarification and Consideration of Community Impact, 30th September
item.description:
Dear Bexley Council, I am writing to enquire whether the Council was responsible for putting up the St George's/Union flags currently displayed along the High Street. If so, could you please clarify the purpose and context behind this decision? In particular, I am wondering whether the Council is aware of the close association of these displays with the "Raise the Colours" campaign, which has concerning origins and messaging (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c626vxyxgj6o). The movement has been criticised for being intimidating towards those of minoritised backgrounds and promoting a narrow and exclusionary vision of English British identity, and I am concerned about the implications of aligning public displays with such a cause - even inadvertently. While it is, of course, entirely understandable to support national sports teams or celebrate local pride, it is also important to consider the wider social context. These flags, in the current climate, ARE making many residents feel uneasy. This discomfort may not always be voiced‚Äîespecially by individuals from historically marginalised or minority backgrounds‚Äîbecause those most affected are often the least empowered to raise objections. By contrast, those championing the displays often can do so loudly, and with relative social confidence or support. With this in mind, I would be grateful if you could share how the Council is monitoring any potential community tension arising from the displays. Are there mechanisms in place to gather feedback from a broad cross-section of residents, including those who may feel alienated by such overt nationalistic symbolism? What solutions has the council considered to help this who may feel intimidated by the displays, and at what point would these be enacted? I appreciate the Council‚Äôs efforts to maintain a welcoming and inclusive public space for all residents, and I hope this feedback can be received in that spirit. I look forward to your response. Kind regards, Rebecca M, Welling
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 88, Bellegrove Road, Welling, London
Report on FixMyStreet
